punch.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to hit someone or something hard with your fist (=closed hand)
punch.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: He punched me and knocked my teeth out.
He punched Jack in the face.
punch.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: to make a hole in something, using a metal tool or other sharp object
punch.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The guard punched my ticket and I got on.
These bullets can punch a hole through 20 mm steel plate.
punch.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: to push a button or key on a machine
punch.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Just punch the button to select a track.
punch.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to move cattle from one place to another
punch.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: a quick strong hit made with your fist (=closed hand)
punch.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The two men started throwing punches (=trying to hit each other).
I managed to land a punch on his chin.
punch.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: a strong effective way of expressing things that makes people interested
punch.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Thirty years after it was written, Orton’s ‘Entertaining Mr Sloane’ still packs a punch.
punch.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: a drink made from fruit juice, sugar, water, and usually some alcohol
punch.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: a metal tool for cutting holes or for pushing something into a small hole
punch.translation[1].note_box[0].section: Rob was so angry that he turned round and threw a punch at the man.
Then I began to land some good punches.
He gave me a punch on the nose.
Who actually delivered the punch that killed the man?
I took a lot of punches but I gave a lot too.
My stomach took a couple of hard punches.
Tyson landed one good punch but it wasn’t enough.
In the fourth round, Lewis produced a knockout punch that ended the fight.
punch.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: the main character in a Punch and Judy show
punch.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a British weekly magazine which was started in 1841 and continued to be published until 2002. It is known especially for its humorous articles and cartoons.
punch.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: a metal tool used for making holes in paper or steel
punch.translation[5].definitions[0].defi: to make a hole in something, for example a card that shows what time you arrived at work or left work
punch.translation[5].definitions[0].exam: Any employee forgetting to punch his card must report it to his supervisor as soon as possible for payment authorization.
